Real-time optimal hierarchy control of HVAC system with maximized ancillary service support in smart buildings: An experimental approach Manish Kumar Yadav Writing – original draft Methodology Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ Ashu Verma Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision Resources Investigation a B.K. Panigrahi Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision Resources Investigation b Dibakar Rakshit Writing – review & editing Validation Investigation a a Department of Energy Science and Engineering, IIT Delhi, New Delhi, India Department of Energy Science and Engineering IIT Delhi New Delhi India Department of Energy Science and Engineering, IIT Delhi, New Delhi, India b Department of Electrical Engineering, IIT Delhi, New Delhi, India Department of Electrical Engineering IIT Delhi New Delhi India Department of Electrical Engineering, IIT Delhi, New Delhi, India ⁎ Corresponding author. This article proposes a real-time optimum control algorithm for Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) units of a commercial building aimed to maximize the ancillary power available for frequency regulation services. First, the prediction of energy consumption of air conditioning zones using long short-term memory (LSTM) is achieved, which helps forecast the aggregated regulation capacity bid of the building in the energy markets. Furthermore, to minimize energy costs and thermal discomfort of building dwellers, an optimization algorithm is designed considering the day-ahead electricity tariffs. Moreover, using installed sensors in a lab-scaled hardware prototype, the proposed algorithm is also shown to be capable of interacting with a Building Energy Management System (BEMS) and investigating the electrical and thermal properties of the HVAC unit. The BEMS controller uses an ethernet protocol to interface with the sensors installed at various operational points throughout the HVAC system. The optimal operation of the HVAC system has been executed with the real-time thermal feedback system, which counterbalances the uncertain thermal load or renewable power availability in the building confronted in real-time operation. The simulation results show the performance of the Artificial Neural Network (ANN) based compressor model in deep learning integrated with the other components of the HVAC unit and thermal model of the air-conditioning zone. Finally, the experimental results display the real-time implementation of multiple thermal and electrical conditions within the proposed control scheme of the HVAC unit. This shows the potential of ancillary services capacity through commercial buildings can be maximized with flexible loads and thereby help in power grid support. Keywords Building Energy Management System (BEMS) Heating Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) system Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) Artificial Neural Network (ANN) Ancillary power services Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Conventional power grids are evolving into smart grids that can handle significant building loads. According to the International Energy Agency [1], electricity power demand in commercial buildings is projected to grow by 1.5 times by the year 2050. In addition, the Energy Information Administration [2] provided a summary of the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) loads, which account for over 50% of the total energy consumption in commercial buildings. In the future, the HVAC system in a building may be revolutionised into a flexible load with increased controllability. This feature of HVAC load could facilitate the building by providing flexibility services to the grid. This demand flexibility potential becomes more evident when an aggregating entity manages a group of buildings at the community level or building clusters. Despite their potential, building clusters have not been well studied regarding flexibility characterization, especially on the flexibility of existing clusters in the operation phase [3]. The operational flexibility differs from the flexibility potential study in the planning, design, or retrofit phase of a building or cluster, as presented in [4]. Operational flexibility applies to existing buildings or systems and attempts to use better operation techniques to achieve energy flexibility. The paper [5] investigates the potential of a commercial building to provide ancillary services for smooth power system operation. It employs a model-based predictive algorithm to estimate the potential amount of flexible power that can be traded in the Swiss energy market in real time. The paper [6] introduced an algorithm that adjusts the regulation capacity of buildings according to the real-time operating conditions of HVAC systems. This algorithm relies on the HVAC technical data sheet supplied by the manufacturer, which is then followed by an optimization algorithm. Paper [7] presents a proposed control algorithm for the HVAC system that aims to participate in the energy market efficiently. As HVAC is a flexible load, it could be controlled or scheduled for the smooth operation of the power system. Two-level scheduling of HVAC units to provide the ancillary power is proposed in [8]. First, it pre-defined the baseline ancillary power and then updated the power availability based on the HVAC power demand. The air handling unit (AHU) fan of the HVAC unit has been controlled in [9,10] to provide the ancillary service, which is fruitful for frequency regulation. An event-based HVAC control scheme also has been presented in [11,12]. These schemes are integrated with adaptive controllers and are suitable for small-scale and large-scale levels. The agent-based control scheme is also used in [13] to control the system. It is integrated with IoT devices deployed in a local system controller. Different methodologies of Artificial Intelligence (AI) have been used for the optimal controlling of the HVAC unit [14–18]. All of these try to minimize the thermal load or operating cost by rescheduling or controlling the system. In Literature, different real-time HVAC control systems for different types of buildings have been proposed. In [19], the HVAC load has been quantified by using semidefinite programming (SDP) formulation, and the problem is reformulated for the optimization of HVAC load demand in real-time. In [20], a practical case study is presented, detailing the implementation of a versatile data-collection and control framework for HVAC systems in a food retail facility. The paper introduces an MPC scheme as a supervisory control layer, enhancing the existing BMS by transmitting informed temperature set points to the legacy controller. Article [21] introduces a real-time management strategy for multi-unit HVAC systems, employing predictive control to optimize thermal comfort and minimize electricity costs through heuristic methods and variable prediction models. In [22], it applies MPC and an ANN in a factory with limited HVAC details. HVAC control in an industrial plant cooling a hospital surgery centre has been explored in [23], ensuring thermal comfort and minimizing energy consumption. In [24], it proposes a scalable control retrofit strategy for enhanced energy efficiency in existing building HVAC systems, seamlessly incorporating data-driven MPC into pre-existing Building Automation Systems (BAS). The HVAC load has been scheduled to minimize the power fluctuation and maximize the occupant's thermal comfort following the Pareto-front optimal solution [25]. While [26] follows the learning-based distributed hierarchical TBSS algorithm for the scheduling of the HVAC system. It combines adaptive learning with distributed learning, where the sensor data is used to learn the model. The energy management problem is formulated as a non-linear problem in [27]. It correlates the machine operating condition and electrical power load in the problem formulation. It aims to determine the machines' optimal operating status and energy cost on the user end. The energy management problem is formulated following the MILP method and solved by using the heuristic method [28]. A stochastic function has been formulated to minimize the energy cost of HVAC and discomfort levels, including the uncertainty in the thermal load [29]. Apart from the energy cost of the HVAC unit, room air temperature, as well as indoor air quality, have been considered in the problem formulation [30]. In the solution of the formulated problem, a real-time algorithm is presented, which follows the Lyapunov optimization technique. The multi-objective problem is formulated in [31]; it minimizes the energy cost of the multi-HVAC unit and maximizes user comfort. The ACODAT concept has been used to self-optimize HVAC units. This technique leads to the automatic management of the HVAC system with optimal operation. An online building energy management system is proposed [32]. For the learning process of BEMS, it uses the Deep-Q learning and deep policy gradient method, which leads to the optimal energy management of a building. In [33], the author formulates the problem of optimal HVAC operation with the help of the Markov decision process of modelling technique. It includes complexity like Predictive Mean Vote (PMV) and uncertain thermal demand. A decentralized control algorithm has been presented in [34,35] following the accelerated distributed augmented Lagrangian (ADAL) method. It also uses the self-organizing swarm intelligence optimization algorithm with fuzzy logic-based control of the HVAC system. The Mamdani fuzzy PI-PD membership function in online mode has been presented to minimize the time response of the HVAC unit by using the NMSS algorithm [36]. Along with this, it trains the network of the CABTSK model offline and online to increase the stability of the system with the help of the gradient descent method. In [37], the LAMBDA algorithm is proposed to control the HVAC, where LAMBDA uses the fuzzy classification rule to solve the control problem of the system. A simulation-based study has been done in [38], which presents an energy management system of a building considering a microgrid equipped with a solar power generating unit and the air condition load mainly depending on the number of occupants in buildings. In the extension of this work, paper [39] presents a two-layer closed-loop control algorithm for the multi-objective optimization problem to minimize energy consumption at a minimum thermal discomfort level. To formulate an optimal control problem it needs a robust and detailed modelling of the HVAC system. In the literature, several models are proposed for HVAC units to simulate and analyze their controlling methodology. Artificial Neural Network (ANN) has been used in [40] to predict the thermal load in the building. A neural network for the adaptive learning and optimal control of the HVAC unit is introduced in [41]. A multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (DRL) algorithm has been used in [42,43] for simulating the HVAC system and control of it following the Markov game theory. A transfer learning integrated with the DRL framework has been proposed to control the HVAC system in [44]. In recent literature [45], for the simulation and analysis of different electrical and thermal parameters of the HVAC system, it uses the pre-defined model on some software like TRNSYS, etc. In those models, certain assumptions bound the user with limited control parameters. In [46], a control scheme for the HVAC system has been proposed to support the frequency regulation. However, it has not considered the controlling of individual motors and pumps connected to the HVAC unit. This literature review indicates that the HVAC operation in a real-time implementable controller and control algorithms has not been explored to that extent. It could countervail the uncertainty in the atmospheric condition, number of occupants, and renewable power generation. Accomplishing this target requires synchronized control of the chiller plant and other parts of the HVAC system. This literature motivates us to work on controlling all the electrical machines of the HVAC unit in a synchronized way to minimize power load demand, which will enhance the ancillary power service capacity of a building for the building's energy management system and grid support. The novel contributions of this paper are thus summarised as follows: • Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) and Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-based Chiller Plant Modelling This modelling approach incorporates AI into chiller modelling, allowing it to integrate seamlessly with various components of the HVAC system. Irrespective of compressor mechanism type, this model is adaptive as per the training dataset. ML-based model accuracy also improves with the updating training datasets which might lead to the chiller efficiency in simulation. • Innovative Hierarchical Control Scheme for HVAC System. The proposed control scheme is designed to minimize electrical power demand while maintaining the thermal comfort of users. The control methodology also portrays a low complexity and quick computational speed making it an ideal component for integration with a building energy management system for real-time operation. • Real-time Optimal Control of HVAC Unit. This optimal control algorithm has been incorporated with a laboratory-scaled HVAC set minimizing its energy consumption with lower thermal discomfort. The proposed control algorithm has been integrated with the grid and solar power availability with its instantaneous power tariff. Ensuring the optimal operation of HVAC with a minimum power tariff, the energy cost for the end consumer is reflected as a minimum electricity bill. With this optimal operation of HVAC, its power demand decreases, resulting in more power availability for ancillary services. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: In section 2, the hour-ahead forecasting of the cooling load is done following the modelling of the different parts of the proposed system presented and section 3 includes the problem formulation. Control algorithms and system flow charts are discussed in section 4, while section 5 elaborates on the simulation of the proposed work and the experimental set-up installed in the laboratory. The real-time execution of the proposed scheme in a different scenario has been discussed in section 5, and section 6 concludes this work. 2 System component modelling This section discusses the modelling of different components used in the simulation of the proposed system. First, it explains the hour-ahead forecasting of the cooling load of the building, and second, it elaborates on the different parts of the HVAC system and R-C model of air conditioning zones. 2.1 Hour-ahead forecasting of cooling load To support the ancillary services in the energy market by building through HVAC scheduling or control, it needed an estimated cooling demand of the air-conditioning zone at least one hour ahead. For the forecasting of the cooling load of a building, the LSTM network has been used. It is explained as follows. 2.1.1 Recurrent neural network A recurrent neural network (RNN) is built to process the input data as sequential information with greater effectiveness. The sequence's individual elements might be processed one at a time by a conventional recurrent neural unit, starting with the first element before adding the second. The problem of disappearing gradients can affect any deep neural network. In response, long short-term memory (LSTM) cells and gated recurrent units (GRUs) were created. The field of machine learning makes extensive use of LSTMs due to their numerous applications, including handwriting detection, speech recognition, machine translation, and time-series forecasting. [47]. 2.1.2 Load data standardization In the training of any network, the training dataset, x → 0 [ n ] , needs to be normalized. After normalization, the mean (μ) and standard deviation of the network's input dataset, x → [ n ] , becomes zero and one respectively. (1) μ → = 1 N ∑ n = 0 N − 1 x → 0 [ n ] (2) ν = 1 N − 1 ∑ n = 0 N − 1 ( x → 0 [ n ] − μ → ) ( x → 0 [ n ] − μ → ) T (3) x → [ n ] = [ d i a g ( ν i i ) ] − 1 ( x → 0 [ n ] − μ → ) 2.1.3 Network training and testing To tune the weights of a neural network, you need a collection of input/output training sets. These inputs are inputted into the network, and the difference between expected and received outputs is measured using a loss function. This error is then propagated back into the network, and the weights are updated using a gradient descent approach. The modified network was tested and compared to the predicted testing results, as shown in Fig. 1 . It indicates that the root mean square error (RMSE) is modest, having a value of 0.0267. 2.2 HVAC system modelling The HVAC system consists of several components which work on a combination of electrical and thermodynamic principles. This work simulates all the different parts of the HVAC system, including the air-conditioned zone, with the help of artificial intelligence and the physical and thermodynamic state of individual components. The integration of the HVAC components and their working flow is shown in Fig. 2 . These modelled components are described in the section below. 2.2.1 Compressor model A compressor includes both electrical and thermal functioning, whereas a typical electric motor provides mechanical power to the compressor, which increases the pressure and temperature of refrigerant inside the cylinder. Artificial intelligence has been employed in this work to express the non-linear operation and properties of the refrigerant. In this work, two ANN-based networks have been modelled to predict discharge pressure (DP) and suction pressure (SP). Both of the modelled networks are connected in a close loop with each other, including various electrical and thermodynamic state variables as the input neurons to the network. At the next step of SP and DP prediction, the instantaneous thermal property of refrigerant (like change in enthalpy) is estimated by using the developed adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) model. In addition to artificial intelligence, the compressor model consists of one physical subsystem to calculate the electrical power demand, mass flow rate of refrigerant, and thermal power absorbed. In the development of ANN, a scaled conjugate gradient (SCG) algorithm has been followed for the fast supervised learning of feedforward neural networks [48]. In the conjugate gradient (CG) algorithm, the scaling factor s → k is termed as follows: (4) s → k = E ″ ( w → k ) p → k ≈ E ′ ( w → k + σ k p → k ) − E ′ ( w → k ) σ k ; f o r , 0 < σ k ≪ 1 where, E ( w → k ) is the error function of the training network, w → k is the weight vector, and p → k is the conjugate system. A total of four levels have been categorized for the overall control of the system, including both the management level as well as end-user level. At the management level, it consists of three different parts which are dedicated to the compressor unit, water pump unit, and air handling unit while the end-user level is dedicated to the response of the thermal comfort point. As in Fig. 5, the central controller generates the three different controlling signals as the operating frequency of the compressor motor, water pump, and AHU fan. It takes the data from multiple sensors (installed at different points in the system) as inputs via cloud storage. This input includes instantaneous room temperature (dry bulb), supply airflow rate, cooled supply air temperature, water flow rate, chilled water temperature, and occupant's thermal voting (Predicted Mean Vote). Based on these inputs, the controller checks for the required cooling thermal power and generates the output signals for the connected machines in the HVAC system. In this work, the controller follows two types of control schemes: one is only PI-based, and another is optimal-PI-based. Following an optimization algorithm with multiple inputs and constraints, the results are obtained as the operating condition of the different parts of the HVAC system. The proposed control algorithm can be applied to any existing BMS by installing some supporting infrastructure. It determines an appropriate zonal airflow, the flow rate of chilled water supply, and compressor operation to minimize the total energy consumption of the HVAC unit with minimum thermal discomfort in the air-conditioned zone. 4.2 Control flow of the proposed algorithm In the above subsection, the mentioned central controller consists of a programmable logic controller (PLC) integrated with MATLAB software. MATLAB fetches all the sensor data connected with the PLC. It checks for the temperature difference between the instantaneous room temperature (dry bulb) and the set thermal comfort point. Simultaneously, it checks for the difference between the instantaneous chilled water temperature and the set value of the chilled water supply. If the system is operating with a non-optimal PI control scheme, the maximum and minimum operating frequency are predetermined for all the connected machines, while in an optimal PI control scheme, the maximum operating frequency is determined by using an optimization algorithm and the minimum point will be fixed due to machine limitations. In the execution of the proposed algorithm on the chiller plant, the operation of HVAC is classified into four different cases based on the temperature differences between room air and chilled water. If the Δ T r o o m and Δ T w a t e r both are positive, it falls in case one if Δ T r o o m is positive and Δ T w a t e r is negative, it falls in case two. If Δ T r o o m is negative and Δ T w a t e r is positive, it is case three and if Δ T r o o m and Δ T w a t e r both are negative, it is classified as case four. In case one and case two, the PI controller will continue with the operating frequency of the AHU fan and compressor according to the logic implanted. If the system runs in case three and case four, the thermal voting of occupants takes place to include one more new input to the controller as the new thermal comfort point. Based on these inputs, the PI controller resets the thermal level of the air conditioning zone and the operating frequency of the chiller plant and other connecting machines. These steps will be followed in both non-optimal and optimal PI control as represented in Fig. 6 . The optimization algorithm provides an optimal operating frequency as per the present thermal and electrical conditions. As the HVAC starts to operate on the resultant frequency, the thermal behaviour of the system changes, which starts to disturb the thermal comfort level. The first impact of the new operating frequency is on the supply air temperature from the AHU. As the AHU fan speed changes, the ACH level changes, and the supply air temperature varies accordingly. As per the ASHRAE standard 62.1, the ACH level for a classroom should be between 6 to 12. To control the high thermal discomfort, the ACH level is regulated. This proposed work, it is regulated based on the value of instantaneous thermal discomfort. Therefore, the optimal frequency of the AHU fan is overruled by the instantaneous thermal conditions. There is one more advantage of over-ruling this rule is that the AHU fan will be able to exchange more thermal power at high thermal discomfort conditions while operating the chiller plant at a lower capacity, which may improve the system efficiency in terms of thermal power. Remark 1 As the nature of the heating and cooling load demand of any thermal zone is quite similar, and both the loads are shiftable and controllable, this proposed algorithm is applicable for heating as well as cooling of the building. In the cooling load, the AHU fan, water supply pump, and chiller unit are being controlled, while in the heating case boiler unit needs to be controlled in place of the chiller unit as per the occupant's thermal feedback. Remark 2 In an HVAC system, there are a number of AHUs connected in a network form to supply the chilled air in multiple air conditioning zones. The proposed control algorithm is applicable to the AHU network. However, due to some experimental limitations, a single AHU is considered a network and is being controlled. 5 Simulation and experimental verification In this work, the proposed algorithm is simulated and analyzed on the MATLAB platform. Along with this, it is tested and verified on the experimental setup installed in the laboratory. It has been discussed in detail in further subsections. 5.1 Simulation The HVAC unit, along with the air conditioning zone, has been simulated for the system as proposed in Fig. 2. The individual component is simulated and integrated on the MATLAB simulating platform to perform as a system and to anatomize the electrical and thermal parameters at different nodes. Fig. 7 shows the training and testing of the modelled network as a compressor's discharge and suction valve. The data used for the training and testing is fetched from the working setup of a compressor unit of the chiller plant. The network for the discharge pressure is trained and tested with the root mean square error (RMSE) value of 2.42, while the RMSE value in the suction pressure network is only 1.536. Fig. 7a and Fig. 7b represent the discharge pressure and suction pressure network, respectively, along with the ANFIS model of refrigerant R-22 properties, as shown in Fig. 8 . It trained the network to evaluate the enthalpy of the refrigerant at any pressure on the suction and discharge node of the compressor. In Fig. 9 , the electrical and thermal simulating performance of the integrated system has been analyzed. Fig. 9a shows the performance of the compressor model where suction pressure goes down due to high thermal load with some initial fluctuations while the discharge pressure will rise up to 2100 kPa with some fluctuations of (+/-) 5 kPa. Concerning time, atmospheric conditions, and the thermal load inside the room, the suction pressure will decrease more while the discharge pressure will remain approximately constant compared to suction pressure changes. Fig. 9b represents the temperature analysis of the water and air at the supply end and inside a room. Initially, the supply water temperature was 22.2 ( deg ⁡ C ) and cooled down to 19.6 ( deg ⁡ C ) in 3.5 minutes. The supply air temperature starts at 26.2 ( deg ⁡ C ) and cools down to 23 ( deg ⁡ C ) in 330 sec meanwhile, at the same time duration the room air temperature goes down to 24.1 ( deg ⁡ C ) from 28.05 ( deg ⁡ C ) in starting of simulation. The power demand by the different HVAC components has been analyzed in Fig. 9c. It reflects that, apart from the operating frequency, the electrical power demand of the compressor unit also depends on the evaporating temperature or the suction pressure. The power demand by the compressor fluctuates (+/-10 W) concerning SP. The AHU fan operates as per the discomfort level inside the room. When the temperature difference between the room temperature and thermal preference is less than 2 deg ⁡ C , the AHU operating frequency is set to 40 Hz. Therefore, the electrical load goes down from 132 W to 79.56 W. All the constant parameters of the compressor motor, Condenser fan, Water pump, and AHU fan have been calculated following the regressive method and listed in Table 2 . 5.2 Laboratory scaled experimental setup To analyze the performance of the proposed system at the field level, a small-scaled HVAC has been set up in a laboratory in Delhi, India, as presented in Fig. 10 . The electrical power rating of all the equipment is mentioned in Table 3 . The installed setup consists of several temperatures and pressure sensors which are interlinked with the different parts of the system to fetch data of operating conditions and the health of the machine. This data is useful for the monitoring as well as controlling of machines in any unhealthy condition or any required operating condition of an HVAC system. At the compressor end of the chiller plant, one set of HP (high pressure) and LP (low pressure) emergency trip switches are also used to prevent any malfunctioning with the compressor due to the low or high pressure of the refrigerant at the suction and discharge terminal. To drive the compressor and water pump, it uses the VFD, and to control the AHU, some relays are being used (as the size of the AHU is low, the discrete control is more favourable than the VFD-driven approach). These drives and switches get controlled by the PLC, which is proficient in executing the switching logic for the number of devices. Solar power generation has been taken into account for optimization only. At the time of compilation of and execution of the optimization algorithm, it will include the solar radiation and well as grid power tariff of that particular time. This PLC is integrated with the chiller plant along with all connecting sensors and some more sensing units connected at the user end and in the ambient. The mentioned integrated system is used to operate the chiller plant at the predefined or un-optimal operating point with any suitable logic. For the optimal control of the HVAC system following an optimization algorithm, the PLC is unified with MATLAB. 5.3 Experimental verification In this proposed work, a scalable control system for the chiller plant is designed which can also be installed in any commercial building with small changes. To analyze the response of the proposed control system, the algorithm is implemented on the experimental set of chiller plants (installed in the laboratory). In the proposed controlling scheme, the operating frequency of the compressor, water pump, AHU, and condenser are treated as control variables. The decision of the numerical value of the control variable depends on the room air temperature (instantaneous) as well as the chilled water supply to the AHU. All the electrical machines in the chiller plant are connected with the VFD which are following the PI-based control. The proposed control method is applied to the chiller plant in two ways, one is non-optimal, and another is optimal PI-control. In non-optimal, the value of the maximum and minimum operating point of the PI control-based machine is fixed. In the case of optimal control, the maximum and minimum operating frequency of the machine vary as per the thermal and electrical conditions of the considered system. The results of the multiple operating conditions including optimal and non-optimal control have been discussed below in this section. Remark 3 The monitoring of system parameters has been done by using the data monitoring facility of the PLC installed with the experimental setup and plotted in MATLAB. 5.3.1 Scenario 1 (non-optimal PI control of HVAC system) The proposed multilevel non-optimal PI control has been implemented on the laboratory-installed HVAC system. The operating data has been recorded and presented in Fig. 6. This figure shows that as per the thermal condition of the room air and chilled water supply the operating frequency of the electrical machine connected to the system will be regulated. It also can be seen that the machines are operating in defined multiple cases (in Fig. 6) as per the thermal situation of the system. Case 1: In this case, it has been considered that the instantaneous room temperature is higher than the set comfort room temperature and the chilled water temperature is also higher than the set value, as presented by Fig. 11 a. Therefore, in this thermal situation, all the connected machines will operate at their maximum operating frequency. Case 2: It is presented in Fig. 11b. In this case, the room temperature is higher than the set temperature, simultaneously the chilled water temperature is going below the set value. In this operating condition of the HVAC system, the compressor is going to operate at the PI-controlled operating frequency and the water pump and AHU will operate according to the instantaneous thermal discomfort in the conditioned zone. The control pattern of the machine, in this case, is plotted in Fig. 11b. Case 3: It presents that, the room temperature meets the set thermal comfort level of occupants while the chilled water temperature does not meet the set temperature level of supply water by the control man. Fig. 11c shows the thermal situation in this condition. This case shows that when the room temperature achieves the set value, the compressor, as well as the condenser both, will be switched off as there is no need for more chilled water irrespective of the set chilled water supply temperature. The switching and controlling pattern of this condition are also shown in Fig. 11c. Case 4: This is the last case of thermal condition when both room temperature and chilled water achieve their respective set values. In this case, the HVAC system runs at the minimum power load condition, as the compressor and condenser will be switched off while the water and AHU operate at the underrating capacity. The thermal condition and operating condition of machines are plotted in Fig. 11d. In case 3 and case 4, the room temperature achieves the set value. The control algorithm aspect the signal of new room temperature in these cases. If there is no such signal, the algorithm will follow the previous set of thermal comfort conditions. 5.3.2 Scenario 2 (optimal PI control of HVAC system) As per the proposed control algorithm, the PI-controlled HVAC system has been integrated with an optimization algorithm. This integral operation sets the optimal operating frequency of different machines connected with the HVAC system. The proposed algorithm is implemented on the laboratory-installed HVAC system and the results are presented below in this section. In the continuation of non-optimal operation at a particular thermal and electrical system situation, the optimization algorithm execution takes place, and the optimal operating frequency is imposed on the machines. Instantaneous room temperature, chilled water temperature, HVAC operation at the optimal frequency, and the electrical power demand of the system are monitored and presented in Fig. 12 b, Fig. 12c, and Fig. 12d. Fig. 12b shows that in optimal operation, the thermal comfort also changes as per the occupants' voting. The same monitoring has been done in Fig. 13 b, Fig. 13c, and in Fig. 13d for another optimal operation in a different thermal and electrical situation of the system. In Fig. 12c and Fig. 13c, it shows that the system goes from non-optimal to the optimal operation or one optimal to another optimal operation. The switching in the operating frequency can be seen very clearly. Remark 4 As the regulation signal from the market could be both positive and negative, here in this present work, the HVAC supports only the down-regulation services, and for the up-regulation thermal storage has been will be responsible, which is assumed to be connected with the chiller plant but not simulated in this work. 5.4 Comparative study In paper [46], it proposed a control algorithm for the HVAC system following a demand response algorithm to respond in the energy market for frequency regulation as per market regulation signals. In [46], the set temperature of the air conditioning zone is predefined, while in this manuscript, the thermal comfort temperature is voted by the occupants and reset by the optimization algorithm. The thermal discomfort level in the air conditioning zone is more than 2deg C for cases 2 & 3 in [46], while in the proposed work, while optimal operation, the difference between the set temperature and actual temperature is 0.1 deg ⁡ C . In [46], it talks about the HVAC as a single unit while, in the proposed work, all the motors and pumps are being controlled in an optimal algorithm to fulfil the thermal demand and regulation services. The AHU fan of the HVAC system has been scheduled as per the pre-planned event [49]. Again it is being controlled at the scheduled time as per the thermal load in the air-conditioned zone. By controlling only the AHU fan, it can provide up to 59.09% of AHU power for the ancillary services. The comparison between [49] and the proposed scheme of this work has been expressed in Table 4 . It explains that if [49] is scaled up as the power rating of the considered HVAC unit in this article, the power saving will be a maximum of 26.36% of rated HVAC power. While in this proposed work, the non-optimal PI control can save a maximum of 35%, and in the case of optimal PI control, it rises to 55% saving of rated power. These power-saving percentages can be changed as per the operating condition and thermal load demand of the air-conditioned zone. Table 5 shows that the energy consumption in non-optimal PI control and Optimal PI control of HVAC systems is 590.46 kWh and 370.8 kWh, respectively, in one month. In one month, 25 working days have been considered, and in one day, 10 hr of HVAC running time is assumed. This quantity of power saved can be put to fruitful use for grid support or ancillary services. Remark 5 This present study considers a scenario where the market can potentially deliver both positive and negative regulation signals. However, we restrict the HVAC system's role to supporting down-regulation services solely. Conversely, we assign the responsibility of up-regulation to a thermal storage system. For the purposes of this work, we assume a thermal storage system is connected to the chiller plant, although we do not explicitly simulate this connection. 6 Conclusion This paper presents the development and real-time implementation of an optimal hierarchical control algorithm for an HVAC system, focusing on the synchronized operation of the chiller plant with the entirety of the HVAC unit and the air-conditioned zone. The primary objective of the study was to demonstrate the optimization of HVAC control for boosting the building's ancillary power capacity and ensuring minimum energy cost to consumers with minimal thermal discomfort. The successful implementation of this system showed its potential for significant energy savings and enhanced participation in the energy market, thereby expanding ancillary service capabilities. Results from the machine learning-based chiller model simulation, paired with the empirical analysis, confirmed the real-time applicability of this control scheme, demonstrating potential electrical power load reduction to 45-47% of the HVAC system's rated power. This saved power could then be redirected to provide ancillary power services to the grid or local community. With HVAC-rated power typically in the 1 MW range for commercial or educational buildings, this control scheme may substantially benefit grid frequency regulation. Moreover, comparing energy costs for a month under non-optimal PI and optimal PI control schemes yielded significant savings, with the latter reducing the costs from INR ‘2850’ to ‘1931’ for consumers in a grid-connected building. coredata.dc:description: This article proposes a real-time optimum control algorithm for Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) units of a commercial building aimed to maximize the ancillary power available for frequency regulation services. First, the prediction of energy consumption of air conditioning zones using long short-term memory (LSTM) is achieved, which helps forecast the aggregated regulation capacity bid of the building in the energy markets. Furthermore, to minimize energy costs and thermal discomfort of building dwellers, an optimization algorithm is designed considering the day-ahead electricity tariffs. Moreover, using installed sensors in a lab-scaled hardware prototype, the proposed algorithm is also shown to be capable of interacting with a Building Energy Management System (BEMS) and investigating the electrical and thermal properties of the HVAC unit. The BEMS controller uses an ethernet protocol to interface with the sensors installed at various operational points throughout the HVAC system. The optimal operation of the HVAC system has been executed with the real-time thermal feedback system, which counterbalances the uncertain thermal load or renewable power availability in the building confronted in real-time operation. The simulation results show the performance of the Artificial Neural Network (ANN) based compressor model in deep learning integrated with the other components of the HVAC unit and thermal model of the air-conditioning zone. Finally, the experimental results display the real-time implementation of multiple thermal and electrical conditions within the proposed control scheme of the HVAC unit. This shows the potential of ancillary services capacity through commercial buildings can be maximized with flexible loads and thereby help in power grid support.
